newsitem.title: UK: Eurobonds quiet amid widespread European holiday.
newsitem.headline: Eurobonds quiet amid widespread European holiday.

text.p: The primary market ground to a halt on Thursday with many European countries closed for a holiday.
Syndicate managers expected little pick-up in activity on Friday ahead of the weekend.

Among today's limited issuance, Lehman Brothers brought a self-led $300 million five-year FRN at 35 basis points over three-month LIBOR during the afternoon while International Finance Corp issued a 100 million Polish zloty two-year zero coupon bond via ING Barings.
The IFC notes were reoffered at 70 percent of face value, giving an annualised yield of around 19.5 percent.
Peru was said to be planning a dollar Eurobond, its first offering on international markets since the mid-1980s, bankers said.
No mandate has yet been awarded for the deal which some dealers said could be for up to $500 million.
Last July Peru said it planned to issue $75 million in Euronotes before the end of the year.

Elsewhere, Imperial Chemical Industries said it was watching international bond markets with a view to refinancing part of a $8.5 billion loan taken out to buy Unilever's specialty chemicals division.
ICI is a rare Euromarket borrower, with just a few deals outstanding. They are a brace of 100 million stg bonds due 2003 and 2005, the last of which was launched in 1987.
Standard & Poor's Corp cut ICI's long-term credit rating to A- from A+ after news of the acquisition. Moody's Investor Service cut ICI to A3 from A2.
Pakistan ministry of finance officials said it planned to launch a Samurai bond of around 10 billion yen with a three- to five-year maturity by early next year.
A Pakistani delegation was in London to meet investors ahead of the launch of a three-year dollar FRN, expected to be launched on May 20.
